content.description: Follow the climber's trail south from the Grocery Store Walls until finding a big roof in the Neanderthal area.  The climb goes up the big dihedral to the right of the big roof.  Climb up to the ledge where you can climb the dihedral, protecting the thin cracks with small nuts or you can layback the flake, protecting  yourself with larger pieces.
content.protection: Bring a few large pieces if pulling the flake or some some small nuts if doing the dihedral.

content.description:
Climb the face to the right of

Cro-Mag Crack

. Pockets and thin edges lead to a nice layback move to reach the first ledge. WARNING! There is a dangerously loose block perched on the ledge. Finish up by following a crack to the top.
content.protection:
TR: Gear in cracks above the climb. You can use the TR setup and a directional in the arch above

Cro-Mag Crack

to climb it as well.

content.description:
This climb is at the north end of the wall that houses

Chicken Wing Crack

. Climb a crack to the first ledge, and head over the bulge.
content.protection: Gear anchor.

content.description: Climb past a small roof and continue up the wall on edges and pockets
content.protection: A toprope.
content.location: South of The Grocery Store Walls is a large block that is detached from the wall. This block has two old bolts on top of the north side. Stratego climbs the right-hand margin of the east-facing side of this block. It is a fun and pumpy toprope problem.

content.description:
This is a super fun lead and a good toprope. It has a lot of pro and super juggy holds.

Start at the base, to the right of "

Oh Face

" on a thick flake. Follow the line to the large ledge, then start in the dihedral leading up to a decent pocketed overhang. Update - I have been informed that this route now features a bolted anchor and can be TR'd pretty easily.
content.protection: Rack up to a Camalot #1, and bring small stuff. Now this route has anchors and can be TR'd.
content.location:
Follow the prominent crack/flake system to the right of a dihedral. It is just to the right of "

Oh Face

."

content.protection: The bottom section is too wide for gear.  The first piece could be a #5 Camalot up high, followed by a #4 Camalot.

content.description:
Climb the short face to the left of

Primal Jam

. The start is the crux. Once you reach the ledge, head over to the arete to finish.
content.protection: Two bolts on top.

content.description:
A huge double tiered roof that is exciting to just look at as you walk by.  To lead it is another story....

Locate this route along the trail from the Grocery Store Wall--you can't miss it.  A downclimb is possible several hundred yards to the North via easy 5th class.

Scramble up 10 feet to a ledge and begin the climb from here.  The first roof is not too bad and takes some good pro.  Pulling over this first lip is tricky, but a nice hands-free rest is found under the second roof.  The exposure is nice for this second roof, which accepts decent crack pro (variable from 0.5 inch to hand size), but large pockets make the route sane.  If you are placing a lot of pieces (especially for the first roof), Hanson notes that you can do the route in two pitches to avoid the extreme rope drag.

This is an exciting route that requires concentration, commitment, and some "hard grit."
content.protection: Stoppers and  good selection of cams from 0.5" to 3".  A #7 hex and a #2.5 Friend will setup an anchor at the top.

content.description:
Start in a small seam (reachy for the shorter) that leads to a ledge. From here, fire up through a fantastic sequence of gastons, sidepulls, flakes, and a cobble to reach an undercling and a large move to the next ledge. This is very fun and thoughtful. It is much more continuous than it looks from the ground. If you are walking south (left) from The Grocery Store, get on this route!

I am adding this route, because it is not listed here. Please update any information if it is your route or you know more about it. I created a temporary route until the correct information is found.
content.protection: 7 bolts to 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is currently the only sport route at the Neanderthal Wall. It is between the large roof system of

Primal Jam

and

Cheater Five

. It is on a clean face looking east.

content.description: At the Neanderthal Wall as you're going south on the trail, go past the large block and find an arete on the wall with a small alcove to the right of the arete.  In the back of the alcove, climb the double cracks.  The first moves off the deck are reachy, but the climb offers a fine, moderate lead.
content.protection:
Standard rack.  Some hexes work well in the cracks.

Per

teece303

:  there is a two bolt anchor with quicklinks.

content.description:
Climb the north-facing section to the right of

The Mosh

.  At the top of the section, climb the east-facing dihedral to the top.
content.protection:
Two 40' slings from a nearby rock and scrub oak make great anchors.

Alternatively, per

Garrick Muehlnickel

: there seems to be bolts and an anchor on top of this climb now.
content.location:
This is immediately to the right of

The Mosh

.

content.description:
This route goes up just right of

Hanson's Folly

.  There are 2 anchor bolts at the top.  You climb onto a ledge and then ascend up the pseudo-dihedral.  There are many small cobblestone pieces to work with, albeit there are a bit sandy.  The beginning might be the crux for some, with a balancy middle section, and juggy finish.
content.protection:
Originally this only had 2 anchor bolts.

Per

Tom Hanson

: this now sports some retrobolts, and per

Bill Farrand

: you can get gear placements between the "widely spaced" bolts.

Per

Andy Hartman

: this is now a sport climb.
content.location:
It is right of the

Hanson's Folly

offwidth.

content.description:
This is a pretty good climb.  Climb the lower crack to a ledge.  You can fill this up with large gear if you want (3-6 inch cams or Bigbros).  At the ledge, choose between more wide crack on the left or a hand crack on the right.  If you are out of large gear (like I was), the right side is the better option.

The left finish is also good.  I just need a couple more big pieces to lead that side.
content.protection: A standard rack, heavy on the big stuff, especially if you climb the upper left crack.
content.location:
The Mosh is a little further southeast from

Primal Jam

.  Look for an offwidth crack at the start with twin cracks above from a ledge (see photo).  There are multiple options for the descent.  There is a class 4 descent to the south near the start of the Cave Wall and at least three class 4 descents to the north before you get to the Grocery Store Wall.

content.description:
"So I turned my mind to understand, to investigate, and to search out wisdom, the scheme of things, and to understand the stupidity of wickedness and the madness of folly."

This route had apparently been toproped in the past but had never been seen a real ascent until now. Start up the nice flake into a couple moves of crack climbing. When the crack thins and peters out, so do the opportunities for gear, making for and engaging second half, but the spice is right, and the holds are sufficient. This route packs a quick punch through its powerful crux but also has some really fun moves before and after.

The route was first climbed as a headpoint ascent with moves and gear placements rehearsed on toprope.
content.protection:
Medium-sized nuts, cams, and an RP for the crux.

A static rope is necessary to build an anchor at the top.
content.location: It climbs the obvious and beautiful arete covered in light green lichen.

content.description:
This route goes up the obvious flake on the left face of the chimney to the right of '

Fat Fingered and Overhung

'. I've seen chalk all [about] the base of this route but not higher up. I'm certain I'm not the first ascentionist, but I am claiming it, unless otherwise corrected.... It is a nice little route, a little exposed, but most climbers will breeze it.
content.protection:
This route can be easily top roped using some longer webbing and the trees on top... some small nuts on top for back up....

If you want to lead this trad, I'd suggest some larger (7-9 hexes) pieces for the crack, [but] either way, there is risk of a pendulum into the chimney face.
content.location:
This is just to the [left] of the

Ada Jam

route.

content.description:
This climb is not in the guidebook.  A fellow climber pointed it out as we were passing by.  He was not sure of the name, but he thought it was called Hanson's Folly.  Maybe Mr. Hanson knows the truth.

Anyway, climb a face with a crack on the left to a ledge.  From here, it is class 1 to class 3 to the chimney.  Climb the chimney to the overhanging offwidth (crux).  Figure out the crux and follow the crack and slab to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack plus I used a #4 BD and #5 Friend at the crux.
content.location:
Hanson's Folly is a little further southeast from

Primal Jam

.  Look for a chimney and an offwidth crack (see photo).

There are multiple options for the descent.  There is a class 4 descent to the south near the start of the Cave Wall and at least three class 4 descents to the north before you get to the Grocery Store Wall.

content.description:
This route goes up the face between Where's The Jam? and

Are You Experienced?

Look for a shallow V-dihedral with a thin crack and a pocket.  Start below the V-corner, climb up it using the crack and pocket.  A mantel helps above.   This climb is quite licheny, but I think it is two-stars pending a little clean-up.
content.protection: One very long sling to a tree off of the cliff top.  Also, use some gear to back it up.

climbs.name: The Fingers Have It
climbs.fa: from Tom Hansen's Climbers Guide to Castlewood

content.description:
The crack right of

Pack the Walls

, in the same chimney.
content.protection: TR - you could lead it with small pro if you are bold.  In a pinch, you can stem out the the detached block that forms a cave.  I happened to stroll through the cave and see a colony of bats about a foot from my head.

content.description:
As you follow the trail down from

Are You Experienced?

around the corner (not the chimney), there is a series of overhanging flakes. Start at the first one at the corner and use the flake to gain the edge. From there, climb the obvios series of finger holds up the face. The flake itself is probably a 5.6.
content.protection: Lots of webbing and a couple of lockers. There are trees on top, but they are a ways back.

content.description:
Cro-Mag Crack is located to the right of "

The Squeeze

". It begins at the entrance to the tunnel formed by the detached block. Climb the right-angling crack to a ledge (crux), WARNING! there [was] a huge, loose, triangular block on the ledge. Climb past the block to the right, and follow another crack to the top.

Per

Anonymous Climber of Offwidths

: as of 11/01/20, the loose block and various other loose rock has been cleaned up.
content.protection:
To lead : small cams to #2 will sew it up.

Toprope: place gear in cracks above.

content.description:
Find this route by hiking South from the Grocery Store walls until you see the large chimney (actually a huge detached block) with two offwidth routes.  Chicken Wing is on the left.  Although the climb is offwidth-sized, much of the route may be done using face holds and stemming to the arete on the left.  Start up the route, then locate a small pocket on the inside left face (for the tricam) at about 8-10 feet.  If you don't have a #5 Camalot (like me) you'll have to run it out to a good rest at about 20ft, otherwise a #5 should fit nicely in this wide section.  A groundfall is probably not likely since the tricam is pretty bomber and once you reach the good ledge, the #4 Friend can be placed here.  At this point, it's tempting to crawl back into the chimney and try to squeeze out the top, but it's just too thin (unless you're 10 years old or something).  It's better to stay on the outside of the offwidth and face the monster like a man (or woman).  Make the final committing moves up the home stretch via tough offwidth jams or liebacking.  The #4 Camalot may be placed near the top of the hard moves in the crack on the right (The Squeeze) or if you happen to have TWO #5 Camalots, the second could be placed on the left.

The anchor on top may be constructed with a long (30 foot) sling by wrapping it around the long block about 15ft back from the edge.  A #2 Friend may also be placed above The Squeeze in a long horizontal pocket.
content.protection: A 0.5 Tricam, #4 and #5 Camalot, and a #4 Friend.

content.description:
This climb is located to the north of

Primal Jam

. It's the only clean dihedral you will run into. Stem the dihedral.
content.protection: TR with gear.
content.location:
It is located to the north of

Primal Jam

.

Downclimb to the north in between Grocery Store Wall and Neanderthal Wall.

content.description:
Locate Candyland just around the corner from

Chicken Wing Crack

on the left (East-facing) side of the large, detached block.

Start in some pockets and cobbles on the face and squirm a #2 Friend into the first pocket.  Now climb up to a small, slanting ledge with a very thin crack at its back (oh, just thought of something--a large Pika hook might be able to fit around this ledge/flake), but if you don't generally carry large hooks around, place the micro cam in the thin crack above the ledge).  A few feet higher the #3 tricam can be fiddled into a large pocket on the face.  It takes a minute to get it right, but it's pretty bomber.  Now, take a deep breath and punch through the crux under the right-facing corner/roof up to a long horizontal finger crack.  Place a good #1 Friend, then pull the roof to the top.  This route is spicy (Cajun style) but does not get an "s" rating if you can place the micro cam and tricam properly.

The anchor on top can be made with two medium/large stoppers in a crack parallel to the cliff edge about 15 back and to the left.  Use a long sling to get the rope over the edge.
content.protection:
The pro is funky on this route, since it's listed as a toprope in the guidebook, but some flexible stem cams ;-0 and tricams can be fiddled into pockets and small horizontal breaks.  Hard Grit, baby.

The following pieces work well: #0, 2, 1 Friends, #3 tricam.

content.description: Hike south of the Grocery Store Wall until you come to the chimney.  Proceed into the chimney until you reach the fork where it opens up.  Now look straight up. This is the route. You basically climb out of the chimney using any means possible. It is a bit awkward but rather fun.
content.protection:
There are a couple usable trees to set up a top rope.  You will need at least 10 foot slings. Try not to get any gear lost in the surrounding cracks.

Per

Jakob Vendegna

: there are now two anchor bolts at the top.

content.description: In the obvious alcove with two cracks in the back, climb the right crack in the back.  This crack is wide, requiring a large piece or two.
content.protection: A few large cams or hexes and some longer slings to set up the top anchor.

content.description: Find a large alcove with wide cracks on both sides of the back of the alcove.  Climb the left crack, which provides a moderate, easily protected lead.
content.protection: A few larger cams or hexes and a long sling to set an anchor on top

pathTokens: Denver Metropolitan Area Bouldering and Buildering
